item.title: 10-Year-Old Spots Museum Error
item.description:
August 6, 2017 - Ten-year-old Charlie Edwards got a jump start on his paleontology career when he noted a mistaken label at the Natural History Museum in London.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/08/06/541877832/10-year-old-spots-museum-error
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: What Changes In Birthing Mean For Evolution
item.description: August 6, 2017 - Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks with biological anthropologist Julienne Rutherford about the long term evolutionary changes possible from a shift in birth practices in the U.S.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 6, 2017 - Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks with biological anthropologist Julienne Rutherford about the long term evolutionary changes possible from a shift in birth practices in the U.S. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/06/541877818/what-changes-in-birthing-mean-for-evolution

item.title: The Call-In: Genetic Engineering
item.description: August 6, 2017 - Last week, a new study was released confirming that scientists had successfully modified human embryos to eliminate a genetic defect. We asked you for your questions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 6, 2017 - Last week, a new study was released confirming that scientists had successfully modified human embryos to eliminate a genetic defect. We asked you for your questions. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/06/541877804/the-call-in-genetic-engineering

item.title: NASA's Voyager Program Turns 40
item.description: August 6, 2017 - NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks to Ed Stone, a chief scientist at NASA, about the Voyager program as it approaches its 40th anniversary. He's 81 years old and has spent half his life on the project.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 6, 2017 - NPR's Lulu Garcia-Navarro talks to Ed Stone, a chief scientist at NASA, about the Voyager program as it approaches its 40th anniversary. He's 81 years old and has spent half his life on the project. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/06/541877776/nasa-s-voyager-program-turns-40

item.title: Erratic Weather Threatens Livelihood Of Rice Farmers In Madagascar
item.description: August 6, 2017 - Climate change is complicating the lives of subsistence rice farmers in Madagascar. For years, the wet and dry seasons arrived predictably. No more. To survive, farmers are looking to diversify.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 6, 2017 - Climate change is complicating the lives of subsistence rice farmers in Madagascar. For years, the wet and dry seasons arrived predictably. No more. To survive, farmers are looking to diversify. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/08/06/541462387/erratic-weather-threatens-livelihood-of-rice-farmers-in-madagascar

item.title: How The Dream Of America's 'Nuclear Renaissance' Fizzled
item.description: August 6, 2017 - Construction of new, modern reactors seemed to herald a new era of nuclear power expansion in the U.S. Now all but one of those projects have been canceled.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 6, 2017 - Construction of new, modern reactors seemed to herald a new era of nuclear power expansion in the U.S. Now all but one of those projects have been canceled. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/06/541582729/how-the-dream-of-americas-nuclear-renaissance-failed-to-materialize

item.title: New Human Embryo Editing Research Reignites Ethical Debate
item.description: August 4, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with Dr. George Daley, the dean of Harvard Medical School, about the ethical discussions surrounding editing the DNA of human embryos and what the future of the technology might look like.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with Dr. George Daley, the dean of Harvard Medical School, about the ethical discussions surrounding editing the DNA of human embryos and what the future of the technology might look like. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/04/541675208/new-human-embryo-editing-research-reignites-ethical-debate

item.title: Brush Yourself Off And Try Again: An Invention Story
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Inventing even the simplest product is a fraught process. Mike Davidson and Mike Smith have learned that lesson the hard way as they seek to change the way teeth get cleaned.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Inventing even the simplest product is a fraught process. Mike Davidson and Mike Smith have learned that lesson the hard way as they seek to change the way teeth get cleaned. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/04/536835736/brush-yourself-off-and-try-again-an-invention-story

item.title: Your ZIP Code Might Be As Important To Health As Your Genetic Code
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Health care forms increasingly ask about more than just medical history. That's because doctors are beginning to understand that patients' stress, and how and where they live, influence health, too.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Health care forms increasingly ask about more than just medical history. That's because doctors are beginning to understand that patients' stress, and how and where they live, influence health, too. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/04/539757759/your-zip-code-can-be-as-important-to-health-as-your-genetic-code

item.title: South Texas Fights Tuberculosis One Blood Test At A Time
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Texas has one of the highest rates of TB among U.S. states. A sweeping effort is underway, largely funded by Medicaid, to diagnose and treat people who don't know they harbor the lung infection.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Texas has one of the highest rates of TB among U.S. states. A sweeping effort is underway, largely funded by Medicaid, to diagnose and treat people who don't know they harbor the lung infection. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/04/539800393/south-texas-fights-tuberculosis-one-blood-test-at-a-time

item.title: Technology Gets Under The Skin
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Last week, a Wisconsin company offered its employees the option to have a chip inserted into their bodies in an effort to help them navigate the workplace. Alva Noë asks: What's the big deal?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Last week, a Wisconsin company offered its employees the option to have a chip inserted into their bodies in an effort to help them navigate the workplace. Alva Noë asks: What's the big deal? http://www.npr.org/sections/13.7/2017/08/04/541106998/technology-gets-under-the-skin

item.title: Scientists Aim For Better, Cheaper Tests For Alzheimer's
item.description: August 4, 2017 - The goal is to find accurate, painless tests that can help doctors diagnose Alzheimer's early and track the progression of the illness and any response to treatment. A few tests seem promising.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - The goal is to find accurate, painless tests that can help doctors diagnose Alzheimer's early and track the progression of the illness and any response to treatment. A few tests seem promising. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/08/04/541393576/scientists-aim-for-better-cheaper-tests-for-alzheimers

item.title: The Archaeologist Who Hunts For Stolen Art
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Christos Tsirogiannis, a forensic archaeologist, explains to Ailsa Chang how he persuaded U.S. authorities to seize an ancient Italian vase from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Christos Tsirogiannis, a forensic archaeologist, explains to Ailsa Chang how he persuaded U.S. authorities to seize an ancient Italian vase from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/04/541538834/the-archaeologist-who-hunts-for-stolen-art

item.title: Uncovering A 'Little Pompeii' In France
item.description: August 4, 2017 - Archaeologists in France have discovered the well-preserved ruins of a Roman town, whose inhabitants appear to have fled to avoid a fire — leaving their belongings and household objects behind.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - Archaeologists in France have discovered the well-preserved ruins of a Roman town, whose inhabitants appear to have fled to avoid a fire — leaving their belongings and household objects behind. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/04/541538827/uncovering-a-little-pompeii-in-france

item.title: Saving Vultures With Nepal's 'Vulture Restaurant'
item.description: August 4, 2017 - A unique conservation attempt is underway in Nepal to save vultures that have nearly been decimated through much of South Asia over the past few decades.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: August 4, 2017 - A unique conservation attempt is underway in Nepal to save vultures that have nearly been decimated through much of South Asia over the past few decades. http://www.npr.org/2017/08/04/541538778/saving-vultures-with-nepals-vulture-restaurant
